title: 109_hr401
content: The "Make College Affordable Act of 2005" allows for a deduction for higher education expenses under Section 221 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Make College Affordable Act of 2005" allows individuals to deduct qualified higher education expenses and interest on education loans paid during the taxable year. Qualified higher education expenses include tuition and fees for the taxpayer, spouse, and dependents. The "Make College Affordable Act of 2005" allows deductions for qualified higher education expenses for eligible students at institutions of higher education, including reasonable living expenses while attending. Amounts paid for qualified expenses are only considered if they are for courses that earn credit. The "Make College Affordable Act of 2005" allows deductions for qualified higher education expenses for eligible students at institutions of higher education, including courses that earn credit towards a degree or certificate at a vocational school. Eligible students must meet specific requirements outlined in the Higher Education Act of 1965. The term 'institution of higher education' is defined in the Higher Education Act of 1965. A 'qualified education loan' is a loan made, insured, or guaranteed by the Federal Government, a State, or a political subdivision of a State, or from the proceeds of a qualified student loan bond under section 144(b). The amount of interest on a qualified education loan for higher education expenses is limited. No double benefit is allowed for any expense under subsection (a). No deduction is allowed under subsection (a) for certain expenses if the taxpayer can claim a deduction under another provision. Additionally, no deduction is allowed if the taxpayer elects to apply a specific section for higher education expenses or if the individual is a dependent eligible for a deduction under a different section. The deduction for qualified higher education expenses is limited to the amount that exceeds any exclusion under section 135 or 530(d)(2) for the taxable year. The deduction is only allowed for expenses related to enrollment at an institution of higher education during the taxable year. The deduction for qualified higher education expenses is limited to the amount that exceeds any exclusion under section 135 or 530(d)(2) for the taxable year. It is only allowed for expenses related to enrollment at an institution of higher education during the taxable year, with certain prepayments allowed for expenses in connection with an academic term beginning during the taxable year or the first 3 months of the next taxable year. Additionally, the amount of qualified higher education expenses is adjusted for certain scholarships and veterans benefits received by the individual for the taxable year. The deduction for qualified higher education expenses is limited to amounts exceeding exclusions under section 135 or 530(d)(2) for the taxable year. It applies to expenses related to enrollment at an institution of higher education, including scholarships and veterans benefits. Married individuals filing separate returns are not eligible for this deduction. The taxpayer and spouse must file a joint return for the taxable year. Nonresident aliens can only apply if treated as resident aliens by election. The Secretary can create necessary regulations. A deduction for higher education expenses is allowed in computing adjusted gross income. Married individuals filing separately are not eligible for this deduction. The table of sections for part VII of subchapter B of chapter 1 of the Code is amended by striking the item relating to section 221 and inserting a new item. Section 221 of the Code regarding higher education expenses is amended, with changes to section 6050S(e) and an effective date of payments made after December 31, 2004.
